comments:
With I20070221-1831 on Windows:
Window > Show View > Other RSE Testing > Test Suites
Select "RSE File Subsystem Tst Suite"
Right-click > Run

The testcase testFTPAccessToHost_ftp_suse_com fails, independent of whether the "Run in background" button is switched on or off.

When I switch to the PDE perspective, import org.eclipse.rse.tests as binary plugin from the target platform, select FTPFileSubsystemTestCase and choose "Run As JUnit Plug-in test", it also fails. The backtrace is:

Assigning to Uwe since I think he is the author of the testcase.
I know this was working before, so it's a regression.
We shouldn't ship M5 with a failing testcase.

Martin, Javier:
I've finally disabled the test case for automated testing now. If modified the test case a little bit, but the main issue here is that the public FTP server I know all limit the connections per ip address. During trying to play with the test case, I've run into this issues multiple times and had to change the server than :-(. As long as we cannot find a server we have under our control and where we can let the test case connect from the same ip as much is it wants, it will be hard to run the test automatically or multiple times in a row.

Another problem is the asynchronous connect and the missing callback capability to signal when the connection is really ready to use. As I stepped through the unmodified code first hand, I had no problem at all as a lot of things completed in background before I stepped over the problematic calls. If currently hold the execution currently hard-coded for 10 seconds as testing for subsystem.isConnected() and ftpservice.isConnected() is not enough. Even if both are connected, the ftp server may still send the login prolog. And as long it is not done, we cannot query for the roots. Basically, I've ended up with a NullPointerException:

java.lang.NullPointerException
   at org.eclipse.rse.internal.services.files.ftp.FTPService.getRoots(FTPService.java:682)
   at org.eclipse.rse.tests.subsystems.files.FTPFileSubsystemTestCase.testFTPReadAccessToRemoteHost(FTPFileSubsystemTestCase.java:152)
...

Javier: Could you investigate it if you have time? The issue is that the _userhome variable is null as the login prolog seemed not to be done. I have no clue if this is a bug or if I just don't use the API right.

Did a slight modification to test for ftpservice.getUserHome() before accepting the connection to be connected ... I've run in another exception:

java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: 0 >= 0
at java.util.Vector.elementAt(Vector.java:432)
at org.apache.commons.net.ftp.FTPClient.getSystemName(FTPClient.java:1859)
at org.eclipse.rse.internal.services.files.ftp.FTPService.connect(FTPService.java:210)
at org.eclipse.rse.internal.subsystems.files.ftp.connectorservice.FTPConnectorService.internalConnect(FTPConnectorService.java:72)
at org.eclipse.rse.internal.subsystems.files.ftp.connectorservice.FTPConnectorService.internalConnect(FTPConnectorService.java:59)
at org.eclipse.rse.core.subsystems.AbstractConnectorService.connect(AbstractConnectorService.java:833)
at org.eclipse.rse.core.subsystems.SubSystem.internalConnect(SubSystem.java:2609)
at org.eclipse.rse.core.subsystems.SubSystem$ConnectJob.performOperation(SubSystem.java:1587)
at org.eclipse.rse.core.subsystems.SubSystem$SubSystemOperationJob.run(SubSystem.java:1274)
at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)
Changing milestone to M6 now that it has been removed from the M5 tests.

FTP testcase should be re-enabled.
There is better API now for connecting with progress monitor and async callbacks.

Contributions welcome. For me it is a "Won't fix". The test cannot succeed in a stable manner as long as we have only public FTP server at hand. The public server will look up the login for the test as they treat the frequent logins as DOS attack (or something like this). The test will make sense to run automatically only if it could launch it's own FTP daemon for the test and shutdown it at the end again.
